    (d) Mr Dee’s returning to the accident site with Mr Bell, and getting into Mr Veigel’s car through a broken window to comfort him before the VRA personnel arrived was, I thought, the mark of a person who had no concern that he might be under suspicion. Further, he did not claim to have given him any physical assistance, although Mr Bell said Mr Dee held his head back so he would not choke. He must have known police would soon come. Although it was suggested by Mr Seton in cross-examination that Mr Dee did not in fact go back down the hill with Mr Bell after the accident, Mr Seton did not in the end submit he had not. Though Mr Hodkinson said he did not see anyone helping Mr Veigel, it does not follow that Mr Dee was not there. Though Mr Lear said he saw a middle aged man seeing to Mr Veigel, and Mr Dee could not have been accurately described as middle aged at the time, that also does not mean he was not exactly where he said he was and doing what he said he was doing. 
    (e) Although, as later appears, police went to the Bega showground to look for the caravan whose number Mr Lear had given them, there were four police officers involved, and only Mr Fowler, one of the four, gave evidence. The fact police did not find the caravan Mr Fowler said they were looking for does not mean Mr Dee hid it or covered it over or took it somewhere else. One would need to know a great deal more about what the other three police officers did and over what period of time before seeing great significance in this piece of evidence. Mr Dee’s counsel submitted the inconclusiveness of the search was, at best, neutral, and I agree.78 My overall assessment of Mr Dee is that he is a person whose evidence I accept on relevant matters. I accept his evidence he made an honest mistake when he told police at Mt Isa the caravan had no back window. I am not persuaded he saw or was a party to any changing of number plates or caravans. Further, as later appears, I conclude that Mr Lear incorrectly recorded the number of the caravan Mr Dee had, shortly before, left on the top of the hill, and also, for reasons I shall come to, made a significant error of identification, in saying the caravan with that number belonged to the offending vehicle.Evidence of Mr E Bell79 He has been a travelling showman all his life. His group normally worked at Christmas time at Batemans Bay. Then they returned their equipment to their depot, which is a farm near Queanbeyan. Then they took three or four “machines” to the Berry show, then to Nowra show, then Bega and then Canberra. He said the Gundagai show was usually on at the same time as the Bega show, and that his son, Mr Elwin Bell Junior, sometimes went to that show. That son had a truck and caravan at the time of the accident. Mr Bell said he could not recall whether he drove a pantech or a truck with a tray. He thought he might have had both kinds. Mr Bell said there were several caravans kept at his Queanbeyan property and usually “a truck or two.” He identified the rig in Exhibit “J” as his “Cha Cha” ride and truck. He said he bought the Cha Cha ride in 1968. The truck was bought to carry that ride. He still has both ride and truck. In 2001 the truck was usually driven by his son, Mr Owen Bell. 80 He identified the truck in Exhibit “K” at page 1037 as one he had owned since about 1994-5. He had had the tray built on it to carry the “children’s truck ride” shown in the photograph. He said the ride had never been covered by a tarpaulin while on the truck. The caravan attached to it had been bought in about 1997, purpose built, from GT Caravans of Melbourne. It was bought for his son Mr Owen Bell to live in, and he had lived in it since it had been bought. The square section at the back with the words “Royal Flair” is a “”pull out”, or room extension. For the first 10 years when Mr Owen Bell lived in it, his child lived in the “pull out”. The caravan was sold some years ago.81 Mr Bell confirmed Mr Dee used to work for him till 2002 or 2003. His duties included driving the truck which pulled Mr Owen Bell’s caravan. (The caravan, he said, is that shown in all three photographs in Exhibit “L”). He said when the vehicles were on the move there was a usual order in which vehicles would travel – smaller trucks, including with caravans, ahead of semis. 82 Mr Bell was cross-examined about the changing of number plates on the caravan Mr Dee said he was towing on the day of the accident. He recalled that the number plate on the caravan had been changed. In 1996 he signed a Vic Roads Declaration to have a new plate issued. The new plate had green numbers. He thought he would then have handed back the old plate to Vic Roads, but conceded he may not have. After that, the caravan continued to be insured under its old registration number. Exhibit ED7, ED6 He said he now has, but did not have then, a caravan with a black and white number plate. It is an antique caravan. He could neither confirm nor deny that in 2001 he had a caravan with a black and white number plate with the number O34209. T498.23 He said Mr Owen Bell’s caravan had never had a black and white number plate.83 He has known Mr Dean Davis for most of Mr Davis’ life. On the day of the accident his son Owen rang him from Bega and told him a serious accident had occurred when Mr Davis had been passing his (Owen Bell’s) vehicle. But he said it had not been Mr Davis’s fault. Mr Bell later became aware it was alleged that Mr Dee had been responsible for the accident. David Hodgson, his manager, rang him about the accident, on the afternoon of the accident. He was aware at the time that his son Owen (as Owen Bell admitted to me) gave a statement to the police without telling them of Mr Davis’ involvement. He told me he knows of, but does not think he has ever spoken to, Stacey Grey.84 Mr Stitt put to Mr Bell inter alia that a realisation of Mr Dee’s involvement in the accident by reason of his caravan’s number plate having been recorded as belonging to the offending vehicle could have been an incentive to remove or alter the plate. He denied such a thing had occurred, T510.5 or that he had wanted to shift the focus of the police investigation way from Mr Dee.Mr E Bell’s Credit85 Mr Seton submitted that Mr Bell was an unimpressive witness who was unreliable on contentious matters. (a) I observed that Mr Bell seemed to take considerable care when answering questions; (b) He appeared to listen carefully to what was put to him.; (c) When apparently unsure of something he would ask for it to be repeated; See for example T487.7 (d) To my observation he is a man of considerable shrewdness; (e) It was his obligation within his business to deal with vehicle registrations and the replacement of defective number plates. He conceded it possible that he had kept an old number plate when getting new ones. T494.38 It is to be recalled that Mr Lear and his daughter wrote down the registration number of the caravan they had seen at the top of the hill, and which they both recognised as the caravan involved in the collision. The number they recorded was O34209. The number on Mr Owen Bell’s caravan on 11 February 2001 was F34209, the plate’s colour green on white. Mr Lear, however, recalled the colour of the plate as black on white. When it was suggested to Mr E Bell he had changed the number plate on the caravan to put the police off the track, he conceded he had changed number plates on vehicles on more than one occasion T499.45 but denied the proposition that he had changed the caravan’s number plate after the accident. In fact there was no evidence Mr E Bell or anyone else ever did change the number plate on the caravan after the accident;(f) As appears below, where I deal with the evidence of Mr Owen Bell, there was a great deal of conflicting evidence about what Mr Owen Bell first told people about the alleged involvement of Mr Davis in the accident, and when he first told them. There were conflicts in Mr E Bell’s evidence about when and by what manner his son first told him of the accident and Mr Davis’ alleged part in it. When he gave evidence to me Mr E Bell, in cross-examination by Mr Barry, gave the following evidence, (over Mr Seton’s objection,) of a telephone call he received from Mr Bell on the afternoon of the accident: 
     
      
       
       “Q. What did he tell [you?] were the circumstances of the accident? 
        
       A. Like Owen told me, when he rang me that there had been an accident along the road going to Bega, not far out of Bega, and I asked him, you know, what happened, and was it our vehicles, what’s happened to them, and he said that he was going up a hill, a fairly steep hill and there was an overtaking lane on that hill and Dean Davis, when his truck was passing Owen, and Owen said that he seen in his rear view, he seen that there was two cars had an accident behind him and Owen, he said he thought it was his car. He said that he told Jamie Dee, he was ahead of Owen with a truck and caravan, he said, “Jamie, I think my car’s been in accident, will you just pull up” So Jamie pulled up, Owen went up to the top of the hill and pulled up and they went back down the hill, run down the hill thinking that it was his car that was involved in the accident. When they got down, it wasn’t his car, it was somebody else and they give assistance there to the people that was involved in the accident until the police and that arrived and after that, they went to Bega show. 
        
        
       Q. What your son Owen told you was, that the accident occurred between two cars while Mr Davis was overtaking Owen’s vehicle? 
        
       A. That’s correct.”  
        T505.1-21 
         
        
       
      
    (He later made it clear that his son had said Mr Davis had not caused the accident.)Although there was objection by Mr Seton to this evidence going in for all purposes I considered it was admissible under section 64(3) of the Evidence Act, and by section 60 was admissible for all purposes, and could see no reason to limit the purpose of the evidence. I could see no unfair prejudice. Mr Owen Bell was to be called.(g) Mr Bell said the call from his son had been on a mobile phone and from the Bega showground. However at the first trial when asked when his son first told him of the accident he said: “[I]t may have been that day or the next”. He told me he “stood by” that answer. (h) Although Mr Bell told me he first heard about the accident from his son Owen, he said at the first trial it had been Mr Hodgkin who had first told him about it. When challenged about that at this trial, he qualified his evidence by saying he first heard of the accident from “David Hodgson and Owen”. (i) It was put to him by Mr Seton that he had never heard from Mr Hodgkin or Mr Bell about Mr Davis’ alleged part in the accident and that his evidence that he had was a creation on his part. He replied: “I’d say you were right off the ball”. (j) Mr Bell said he had a conversation with Mr Hodgkin on the afternoon and evening of 11 February, T512.30 and that Mr Hodgkin had given him a description of the accident as relayed by Mr Bell. That description was the subject of objection and, having conditionally admitted it, I now reject it.  
     
     These are my reasons:  
      
     (a) Mr Seton attacked Mr Owen Bell’s credit, and the evidence could have been admissible to restore credit under s.108(3),  
     Evidence Act 
     ;  
      
     (b) I could not see its admission adding unduly to the trial’s already considerable length;  
      
     (c) But I could see some unfairness to Mr Davis, if Mr Hodgkin were not called; 
      
     (d) I did not consider the evidence could have any but minimal weight; 
      
     (e) I could not see the evidence as having any importance in my re-evaluating Mr Owen Bell’s tattered credit; 
      
     (f) I took into account that the evidence was hearsay on hearsay, but that no jury was involved, so as a judge deciding relevant issues I would not give the evidence undue weight if it went in.  
      
    (k) My observation when dealing with Mr Dee about the failure of the Dee/Bell interests to call Mr Hodgkin, applies equally to Mr E Bell’s evidence. As to what Mr Hodgkin told Mr E Bell on the day of the accident, and in particular whether there was any reference to Mr Davis’ involvement, I infer Mr Hodgkin’s evidence would not have assisted the case of Messrs Dee and E Bell. (l) Mr E Bell said that he had not been aware at the time that Mr Dee had been identified as the offending motorist by reason of the number plate on the caravan and had not become aware of that until he had been talking to the solicitor acting for him. T507.10 There was no evidence to contradict that. (m) Mr Bell admitted he had in the past falsified documents to obtain a financial advantage. T512.10 86 Mr Bell denied he had been the anonymous police informant. 87 While he has been dishonest in the past in order to obtain a financial benefit, it does not follow that I should reject all that Mr Bell has to say. Nor do the other matters I have referred to, whether alone or in combination, cause me to reject his evidence on significant matters. On most significant matters, I accept Mr Bell’s evidence. I shall return later to consider whether I accept what he told me about being told of Mr Davis’ involvement at the time of the accident, after I have considered the evidence of Mr Owen Bell. Evidence of Mr Owen Bell88 Mr Bell is a son of Mr E Bell. He was at the Nowra show in February 2001. At about 9.00 am on the day of the accident he left Nowra, driving a semi trailer carrying a “Cha Cha” ride. Mr Dee left before him, driving a Hino truck, towing the caravan then used by Mr Bell as his home. It had been his home for ten or more years. Mr Bell told me that his caravan was always hauled by the Hino and that Mr Dee was always the dedicated driver. 89 Mr Bell identified the truck and caravan in Exhibit ‘K’ as the relevant truck and caravan. He said the show ride carried on the back of the truck was made especially for that truck. After 11 February 2001 he continued to use the caravan as his home for four or more years. Then he bought a smaller one. The old one was then renovated and sold. 90 He told me that the truck in Exhibit ‘L’ is the Hino which at the time of the accident pulled his caravan. The ride shown on the back is the one it carried at the time. The caravan is the one he lived in before and after the accident. The photographs on pages 1038, 1043 and 1044 in Exhibit “L” show the same caravan. 91 On 11 February 2001, Mr Dee left Nowra approximately five minutes before him. Mr Dee always went on ahead of Mr Bell. They stopped at a point 10-15 kilometres out of Narooma to check the tyres and loads. Then they proceeded towards Bega, with Mr Dee still in front.92 He came to Stoney Creek Bridge. There were cars behind him. He recalls only Mr Dee being in front of him. He was in the left overtaking lane after the bridge. Mr Dee was 100 metres in front of him when he moved into the left lane. Six to eight cars passed him in the right lane. 93 As he drove up the hill he changed down gears and reduced speed. The cars were travelling at 90-100 kilometres per hour and his semi at 70. Most of the cars passed him. He saw a white Isuzu truck and cream coloured caravan go past him. He noticed Mr Dean Davis was the driver of the truck. When the truck and caravan passed him, they returned to the left lane and kept going, eventually disappearing from his sight. Mr Bell described the Isuzu truck as having been smaller than the Hino, with a body on the back made of aluminium or steel, with a “square” shape, white in colour. The body was “fully covered”. The caravan, he said, was twelve to sixteen feet in length; he thought it had side windows but no back windows. Through his rear vision mirror, he saw a car go across the road and collide with an oncoming one. He called Mr Dee on his CB radio and asked him to stop. He owned a green coloured Holden Commodore at the time. It was being driven from Nowra by a Bell employee. He thought the car he had seen behind him had been his. 94 His then fiancée Melissa, was his only passenger. She had been asleep, but awoke when he began to speak on the CB. He stopped at the top of the hill where he saw Mr Dee’s truck with caravan parked on the side of the road. 95 He parked his truck behind Mr Dee’s. All three ran down to the scene of the accident. He then realised the green car he had seen was not his. While they were there, Mr Dee got into the injured man’s car, while he, Mr Bell remained on the roadside, talking to Mr Dee through the car window. While he was there he also spoke to a lady (who I infer was Ms Broughton.) 96 Police arrived. He gave them his name and number and said where he could be contacted. He and Mr Dee and Melissa then walked back to the trucks. 97 He got straight back into his truck. Mr Dee left first. Mr Bell then travelled to the Bega Showground, where he set up his caravan next to Mr and Mrs Hodgkins’ caravan. 98 The day after the accident he spoke to police. He did not tell them of Mr Davis’ involvement in the accident. But he told them of the involvement of a truck pulling a caravan. He gave police a description of the truck which was different from the description he gave me. For example he told police the truck was a small truck like a Toyota Dyna. 99 He told police the truck had passed him just before the accident, and that he did not know whether the truck was a pantech. He admitted to me that by giving that description and by not telling police he had seen Mr Davis, he had withheld important information from them. 100 In a signed statement he gave Bega police on 13 February 2001 Exhibit BJ he said, amongst other things, the following: 
     
      
      “…[A]bout halfway up the hill, …I looked in my rear vision mirror and saw a small truck like a white Toyota Dyna which was towing a caravan had moved up beside me and was passing me in the right lane. The Toyota Dyna was moving a lot quicker than me. He passed me and I had another look in my rear vision mirror and saw a white Datsun station wagon, which was going the opposite way to me, skidding along the guard rail, probably for about 20 to 30 metres. I looked back ahead and looked back into the rear vision mirror and saw a dark green Holden Commodore, that was travelling south going across to the wrong side of the road and it hit the front of the Datsun”. 
       
      
    101 Another description of the truck and caravan he gave police at the time was: 
     
      
      “The Toyota Dyna truck that passed me just before the accident was an older model, probably around the 1980 mark somewhere. It was white and had a white body. I don’t know if it was a pantech. The caravan it was towing was only a short one, about 12 foot long, from what I remember about it. I think it was white, or a light colour and it might have had a green and brown stripe on it.” 
      
    102 In cross examination by Mr Seton he gave me the following description of what he observed of Mr Davis’ truck when it was still behind him: 
     
      
      “Q. Mr Bell, some few questions ago I asked you whether when you first saw the truck whether it was in the overtaking land and you said it was. Was it all in the overtaking lane? 
       
      A. No, not till I got it round back of my trailer, coming from the left lane into- coming like driving up the side of me, when it’s overtaking you. 
       
       
      Q. Very well. So when you first saw the truck, the first time you laid eyes on this truck, firstly you were looking in the rear view mirror, correct? 
       
      A. Yes. 
       
       
      Q. And was any part of the truck in the overtaking lane? 
       
      A. When I first looked into my rear vision mirror, when he was coming out from the left lane half his truck was in the- going in the right land, with the blinker— 
       
       
      Q. Half his truck was in the overtaking lane and the rest of it appeared to be, did it, in the lane behind you which you were in? 
       
      A. Yeah, coming on an angle like he’s going to pass you. 
       
       
      Q. It had its indicator on, you say? 
       
      A. Yes. 
       
       
      Q. That was the first time you were ever aware there was a truck behind you for the last 10 to 15 kilometres? 
       
      A. Yes.”  
       T558 
        
       
      
    103 Later he was asked 
     
      
      “Q. It didn’t seem that his truck and caravan was in any way preventing the white Datsun from coming into the correct lane? 
       
      A. No”  
       T560 
       
      
    104 Later he agreed he had given the following evidence at the first trial: 
     
      
      “Q. At the time that the green Commodore crossed the double unbroken lines, where was Dean Davis’ rig? 
       
      A. He was gone around the corner, he was gone”.  
       T561 
        
       
      
    He told me he stood by that answer. Then he was asked:  
     
      
      “Q. So he was actually out of sight, was he, when you saw the green Commodore cross over? 
      
      
      A. He was out of sight, I can’t remember.” 
       
        
      
    105 Later when cross-examined by Mr Black he gave the following evidence: 
     
      
      “Q. At the time that you made [your?] statement to the police, you knew that if you withheld information from the police or told lies to the police, that you were exposing yourself to the risk of getting into serious trouble, correct? 
       
      A. Yes. 
       
       
      Q. You say that at the time of this accident, you understood that Mr Davis didn't have a driver's licence, correct? 
       
      A. Yes. 
       
       
      Q. Do you say that that's the reason that you chose to mislead the police about Mr Davis being there? 
       
      A. Yes. 
       
       
      Q. Isn't it the case that you thought that Mr Davis might get into trouble that was a lot more serious than simply not having a driver's licence in respect of this accident? 
       
      A. Yes. 
       
       
      Q. That's because you knew that Mr Davis had been driving his truck in such a way that he had caused the accident, didn't you? 
       
      A. No. 
       
       
      Q. Well, why would you expose yourself to such serious trouble when the worst that could happen to Mr Davis, if your account was correct, was that he might get into trouble for driving without a driver's licence? 
       
      A. I don't know. I've got nothing to say. 
       
       
      Q. It's because you knew that he would get into a lot more serious trouble than that because he'd in fact caused the accident? 
       
      A. He didn't cause the accident because he was up past me. 
       
       
      Q. He wasn't past you at all, was he, he was at the back of your truck-- 
       
      A. No, he was past me up the front of my truck. 
       
       
      Q. He drew out as the Commodore was attempting to overtake your truck and the manner in which he drew out was such that the Commodore had to go on to the wrong side of the road. 
       
      A. Dean was up past me truck, he was up past me truck and the Commodore was still coming over the bridge. 
       
       
      Q. The reason that you tried to conceal Mr Davis's presence at the time of the accident was because you knew that he might get into a lot of trouble because he caused the accident. That's right, isn't it? 
       
      A. He didn't cause the accident at all.”  
       T610.37-T611.30 
      
      
    When he was cross-examined by Mr Barry this evidence was given: 
     
      
      “Q. Then taking your mind back to the accident you did see the green Commodore for a very short period of time before the collision with the car coming in the other direction, didn't you? 
       
      A. Yes, I seen him up on the other hill. 
       
       
      Q. But I'm talking about when you were going up the hill, just before the accident and before it actually had the collision with the white car you had seen it before that, hadn't you? 
       
      A. Yes. 
       
       
      Q. I think you saw it going across the wrong side of the road? 
       
      A. Yes. 
       
       
      Q. And I think at the time you saw it going across the wrong side of the road the vehicle that was being driven by Dean Davis was partly in the overtaking lane and partly in the inside lane? 
       
      A. No, he was overtaking, yeah, like coming out from behind me. 
       
       
      Q. He was coming out, at the time when you saw the green car going over the wrong side of the road Dean Davis' vehicle was in the process of moving out to overtake you? 
       
      A. No, Dean Davis was already overtaking me, he was up where my truck— 
       
       
      Q. But he was partly in the overtaking lane and still partly in the other lane, wasn't he? 
       
      A. No. No, he was in the right lane. 
       
       
      Q. When you gave evidence on 9 December 2004 what you said at page 1289 line D of the transcript before the judge on that occasion was, before you saw Mrs Broughton start to go out that he was still coming into the left lane? 
       
      A. Still coming in the left lane? 
       
       
      Q. That's what you said? 
       
      A. Can't remember that.”  
       T613.46-T614.30 
      
      
        
      
    106 The proposition that Mr Bell was lying to cover up for Mr Dee appears from the following cross-examination by Mr Seton: 
     
      
      “Q. Was it not the case that in fact Jamie Dee was travelling behind your vehicle? 
       
      A. No, Jamie Dee was in front of my vehicle. 
       
       
      Q. Was it not the case that he in fact overtook your vehicle as you went up the hill? 
       
      A. He never overtook me once, he was in front all the time. 
       
       
      Q. Was it the case that you saw the collision and formed the view that Mr Dee had caused it? 
       
      A. Jamie never caused it because he was in front of me 100 metres. 
       
       
      Q. Was it the case that you then got on the CB radio and told him about the accident and told him to pull over? 
       
      A. I got on the CB radio and told him that my car’s been in an accident, to pull up top and we’ll run back down and see if it was my car.”  
       T565 
      
    107 Mr Bell told me that he had been trying to cover up for Mr Davis, by not telling police about his involvement, and giving them misleading descriptions of his vehicle. He said:  
     
      
      “I didn’t want to get him in trouble or anything like that because we’d been best mates since we were little.” 
       T550.33-34 
       
      
    (As later appears, Mr Davis had a different version of the closeness of the relationship.)Credit of Mr Owen Bell108 It is hardly surprising that Mr Bell’s credit became the subject of attack. There was very good reason. For example: (a) He conceded to me that he had knowingly withheld from Bega Police important information. T550.33 He said he had done so as he and Mr Davis had been “best mates since we were little”. T550.33(b) Having made that claim he told me he could not remember and did not know what Mr Davis could be blamed for.(c) Mr Bell admitted when cross-examined by Mr Seton that he had lied when telling Bega police “I don’t know if it was a pantech”, because in fact he knew it had been a pantech. However when cross-examined at the first trial on this issue he denied that statement to police had been a lie.(d) He told me he had first seen Mr Davis driving Mr Davis’ truck when the truck was alongside him, when he had seen Mr Davis through the passenger side window of Mr Davis’ truck. T549 But at the first trial he told Judge Coorey he could only see the passenger in Mr Davis’ truck when it went past, and that he had seen Mr Davis in his rear vision mirror T555; this had occurred before Mr Davis’ truck had come alongside. He told me he did “not really” stand by the answers he gave to Judge Coorey. But he maintained he had seen Mr Davis driving the truck.(e) (i) He was cross-examined on whether the Bell interests had been a party to swapping number plates or caravans to divert police attention from Mr Dee, once they knew someone had given police the registration number of his caravan. At the first trial Mr Bell gave this evidence about a bystander’s taking his registration number and passing it on: 
     
      
       
        
        “A. When we were down the bottom at the accident a man pulled up and got my rego number off my caravan and come down and said to a lady, ‘Here you are, this is my number, I seen it all happen’, and he took off. 
         
        Q. So this is the situation. You knew that that man had gone up the hill in his car, correct? 
         
        A. No, I didn’t see him do it. 
         
         
        Q. Isn’t this the— 
         
        A. My girlfriend was standing there when he gave the number and the rego number and that to the lady and she give it to the police.” 
         T570 
          
         
          
         
        
       
      (ii) He told me he could not remember that. What he said to me on the topic of number plates having being recorded was: 
       
        
         
        “My fiancée was standing right next to him and she seen him write his name and number down and said, I seen everything. Nothing about a numberplate or anything like that.”  
         T570.20 
        
       
      
     
     
      
      (iii) He went on to tell me he knew nothing about a man’s having given his registration number to someone at the accident site. But at the first trial he gave this evidence: 
       
       
        
        “Q. So is this the position. You were down at the scene, you became aware that a witness had written out a registration number which you understood had been taken from your caravan? 
         
        A. Yes.”  
         T571 
         
          
         
        
       
      
    Asked if he stood by that answer he told me: “No, I stand by- can’t recall”. (iv) Then he gave the following evidence: 
     
      
       
        
        “Q. Mr Bell, by the time you left the site, the scene up at the top of the hill, by the time you drove away, it was your belief wasn’t it, that someone had got the registration number of your caravan, do you agree with that? 
         
        A. I do not know. I don’t know if anyone got my rego. 
         
         
        Q. It was your belief when you drove away from the top of the hill that that witness, that there was a chance that that witness thought that your caravan had caused the accident? 
         
        A. Yeah, he probably thought that my caravan caused the accident, but my caravan was in front of me all the time. 
         
         
        Q. Was it the case that as you drove away from the top of the hill that you were concerned that there was a witness out there who might have thought that your caravan was to blame for the accident? 
         
        A. No. 
         
         
        Q. Was it the case that that was something that troubled you or concerned you? 
         
        A. It didn’t concern me at all”  
         T571 
         
          
         
        
       
      
    (f) Police spoke to Mr Bell at Mount Isa, some six months after the accident. He told me that although he knew at the time he should have told them of Dean Davis’ having been in the truck, (as he should have told Bega police about it,) he had not done so, and had therefore knowingly misled them.(g) He told me he would be willing to lie to police to protect a friend T574: but that although Mr Dee had been a friend, he would not have lied to protect him T574: (h) The first time Mr Bell told anyone involved in investigating the case of Mr Davis’ involvement, was in January 2004, when he was interviewed by an insurance investigator. T575 He said his understanding of what would happen if the claim against Mr Dee succeeded was “I just thought it’d – be in a bit of trouble, that’s all”.(I) Although he told me the only person he told about Mr Davis’ involvement, on the day of the accident, was his father, at the first trial he said that after the accident he had told David and Sharon Hodgkin. He told me that he could not remember if that had been “the truth” but then said that what he had said at the first trial had been “all the truth”. At the first trial he said he had also told his fiancée Melissa, and Mr Dee, as the three of them were walking back up the hill after going back to the scene of the accident. However he told me he could not now recall telling anyone apart from his father. T578 But at the first trial he was asked whether he had told his father on the day of the accident and his answer was “No, I never told me father”.(j) Although he said at the first trial he had told Mr David Hodgkin of Mr Davis’ involvement on the day of the accident, when insurance investigators spoke to him on 29 January 2004 he said: “I did not mention that it was Dean Davis in the vehicle that overtook me to David”. He told me that statement had been a truthful statement. T581 Although he said at the first trial that he had told Mr Dee of Mr Davis’ involvement as they had walked back up the hill, he told the investigators he had never told him. He told me that what he said to the investigators was true, and that until he signed the statement for the investigator, he had in fact only told his father. When Mr Seton put to him that he had told Judge Coorey of having told Mr Dee about Mr Davis on the day, he said, “I can’t recall but Jamie was there with me all the time so he knew who was driving the truck.”  T578.26(k) Although he told me that the first time he had mentioned Mr Davis’ involvement to his father was on the day of the accident and by telephone, he told Judge Coorey that he had first told his father when he had seen him at the Canberra show, which is the show the Bell family went to after the Bega show.(l) He told me he had not been trying to put police off the track by giving them a false description of the truck, although he conceded he had given them a false description.(n) He agreed in cross-examination that show people stick together. Asked if he was sticking to Dean Davis in the witness box he said, “I hope so.” Later he was asked, “You know that you’re sticking to your mate, even now, don’t you?” and he said, “No.” Then when he was cross-examined by Mr Stitt this evidence was given: 
     
      
      “Q. Not only did you know that Dean Davis was not licensed at the time of this accident but you also knew that he wasn't licensed to drive a truck, didn't you? 
       
      A. Yes. 
       
       
      Q. So that you knew that he was driving the truck because he was not licensed and that that was an offence? 
       
      A. Yes, it was. 
       
       
      Q. That was one of the reasons that you were keeping his identity concealed, wasn't it? 
       
      A. Yes. 
       
       
      Q. Did it also occur to you that another reason to keep his identity concealed was because he was directly involved in this accident? 
       
      A. No. 
       
       
      Q. But he was directly involved in the accident, wasn't he? 
       
      A. No. 
       
       
      Q. Well he was pulling out beside you at the time the green car collided with the Datsun? 
       
      A. He was in front, he was up the front of my truck. 
       
       
      Q. Do you think that by saying that he was up the front of your truck that you're still protecting Dean Davis? 
       
      A. No. 
       
       
      Q. I beg your pardon? 
       
      A. No. 
       
       
      Q. But if your version is correct that he was up the front of your truck and passed your truck, then on your version Dean Davis had done nothing wrong, had he? 
       
      A. No. 
       
       
      Q. So on your version there was nothing to protect him about, so far as this accident was concerned, from the police was there? 
       
      A. No. 
       
       
      Q. But that's exactly what you did, wasn't it? 
       
      A. No. 
       
       
      Q. Protect him? 
       
      A. No. 
       
       
      Q. From the police? 
       
      A. No. 
       
       
      Q. But you did because you didn't reveal his identity to the police, you've told us that? 
       
      A. All right. 
       
       
      Q. Isn't that the truth, Mr Bell? 
       
      A. It's got to be the truth, yes. 
       
       
      Q. It's got to be the truth, hasn't it. You see, what you're doing, I suggest, is that you know that Dean Davis caused this accident and you know that it was his driving which forced the green car off the road, onto the other side of the road, and that you are still doing your best to help him, aren't you? 
       
      A. No. 
       
       
      Q. Well do you think that if your version of the accident was accepted by the judge that that would help Dean Davis? 
       
      A. I don't know. 
       
       
      Q. Come on, Mr Bell, you do know? 
       
      A. No, I don't. 
       
       
      Q. You don't know, is that what you're saying to his Honour? 
       
      A. Yeah. 
       
       
      Q. If your version of Dean Davis's action is correct then he had nothing to be concerned about so far as the accident was concerned, isn't that so? 
       
      A. Yes. 
       
       
      Q. But you were concerned because you wanted to protect him? 
       
      A. I'm not protecting him. 
       
       
      Q. I thought you just told us that the showmen stick together? 
       
      A. Yeah, we do. 
       
       
      Q. Well aren't you sticking with him now? 
       
      A. I'm always sticking with him. 
       
       
      Q. You're always sticking with him? 
       
      A. Yeah. 
       
       
      Q. You're sticking with him right now, aren't you? 
       
      A. Yeah.” 
       T621.46-T623.34 
       
        
      
    (n) When he was cross-examined about the fact that he told me the first person he told about Mr Davis’ involvement was his father, and he was reminded that at the first trial he had said he had told Sharon and David Hodgkin on the day, he said somewhat unresponsively: “They knew Dean was coming to Bega and they seen him at Bega.”  T577.15 (see also T589) There was no direct evidence that anyone ever saw Mr Davis at Bega at that time. Ms Grey gave no evidence they went to the Bega show ground after the accident. I infer Mr and Mrs Hodgkins’ evidence would not have given support for Mr Bell’s evidence about what, if anything, he told them, on the day of the accident, concerning the accident. I draw the same inference from the failure of the Dee/Bell interests to call Mr Bell’s former fiancée, Melissa, as Mr Seton urged that I should. I give no weight at all to the hearsay concerning Mr Davis’ having been seen at Bega that day. That evidence has the hallmarks of something Mr Bell made up on the run to give support to his assertion of having told Mr Hodgkin of Mr Davis’ involvement. I find Mr Bell did make it up. (o) At the first trial when he was cross-examined about the possibility number plates had been swapped he was reminded he had been aware someone had given his caravan registration number to a lady at the scene. He was reminded of his earlier evidence then cross-examined about it by Mr Seton: 
     
      
      “ ‘Q. It was at that point when you realised that maybe there was someone out there suggesting that the vehicle carrying your registration number was to blame for the accident. Is that right? 
       
      A. No, me and Dean had the same numberplate but there's one number different in it.’ 
      
      
       
      Do you stand by that answer that you gave on that occasion? 
       
      A. Like I said yesterday, my girlfriend told them, told me that a fellow did give a piece of paper with his name and phone number and said, I seen everything. That's all I'm saying, that's all I can say about that. 
       
       
      Q. But Mr Bell, what I'm asking you is simply about the evidence you gave at the first trial. The answer that you just gave, no, that I just read to you, I should say, "No, me and Dean had the same numberplate but there's one number different in it"? 
       
      A. I can't recall that. 
       
       
      Q. Was that answer that you gave to Judge Coorey correct? 
       
      A. Like I said, my wife told me that a fellow give her a phone number, and his name to the lady, that's all I know. 
       
       
      Q. I'm asking you about your evidence on the last occasion. Was that answer that you gave before his Honour Judge Coorey, correct? 
       
      A. I can't recall. 
       
       
      Q. You know as you sit here, don't you, that the answer you gave that I just read out, was false? 
       
      A. I can't recall. 
       
       
      Q. You were lying when you gave that evidence on the last occasion, weren't you? 
       
      A. No, I wasn't lying.” 
       T594.9-40 
       
      
     There was no other evidence Mr Davis had a similar number plate to Mr Bell’s. The issue was explored further T595 when the following evidence was given: 
     
      
      “That evidence that you gave on the last occasion at the first trial was totally made up by you, wasn't it? 
       
      A. I can't remember saying that at all. 
       
       
      Q. Because you said whatever came into your mind if you thought it would help your story, didn't you, when you gave evidence on the last occasion. Next question, line I. 
       
       
        
        "Q. So is this the position, you were down at the scene, you became aware that a witness had written out a registration number which you understood had been taken from your caravan? 
         
        A. Yes. 
         
         
        Q. You thought there and then, did you, 'well, wait on, that might be a problem because my number is very similar to Dean Davis''? 
         
        A. Right. I didn't know that to this year when I see him in Bendigo show, he told me about that." 
        
       
       
      That answer that I just read out was entirely false, wasn't it? 
       
      A. No. 
       
       
      Q. You never had a conversation with him at Bendigo about number plates, did you? 
       
      A. No.”  
       T595.5-28 
       
      
    (p) At the first trial Mr Bell said he had had a conversation with Mr Davis at the Bendigo show, when Mr Davis told him his caravan registration number was very similar to his. But Mr Bell told me he had never had such a conversation.The precise reason Mr Bell told the many lies he has told may have been one I heard nothing about, although some were explored. He may well have lied to help stop Mr Dee from being falsely accused of having caused the accident. He may have lied so he would not be correctly accused. However, people lie for all sorts of reasons – sometimes apparent and sometimes not: R v Jovanovic (1997) 42 NSWLR 520 at 542 (Sperling, J). 109 Despite the above, some of Mr Bell’s evidence struck me as honest. For example the following evidence was given: 
     
      
      “…you were there when the accident happened and you tell us that you brought your truck to a halt as soon as you safely could and went back to help the people in the accident? 
       
      A. I didn't go back to help the people, I went back to see if it was my car. 
       
       
      Q. Okay, but when you went back you stayed there for a while and you were there even before the police arrived and you did, in fact, help people who were hurt in the accident? 
       
      A. Yes. I never helped, Jamie did. That's why I had to stay back because Jamie was in the car.” 
       T606.35-44 
      
    110 Further, Mr Bell stayed at the scene of the accident for a considerable time after it occurred and gave his telephone number, name, address and registration number to Senior Constable Milton when he arrived, and said he would be at the Bega show. This does not strike me as conduct of someone keen to get away from police and police investigation. However it is probable that it was only after he had arrived back at the scene of the accident when he learned someone had apparently taken down the number of Mr Dee’s caravan.111 Mr Seton submitted Mr Bell gave me an “outrageously wrong version of the accident”. Although I agree with Mr Seton it seems unlikely the truck and caravan he associated with the accident were already virtually out of sight, and ahead of him, when the accident occurred, I thought his description of the course of Mr Veigel’s car as skidding along the Armco railing for twenty to thirty metres quite feasible. See for example photographs 1, 2, 7 and 9 in Exhibit B. He described Mrs Broughton’s car as ‘up on two wheels’, which description Mr Seton attacked, but to an observer of a fast moving event that does not seem an unlikely perception. Mr Seton also submitted Mr Bell had no reason to give an exculpatory version of the collision, given he had gone to the lengths of letting down one of his friends. However I consider Mr Bell may well have felt guilty about informing on someone he regarded as a friend, so offered a sanitised version. 112 Mr Bell is aged thirty-eight. He went to boarding school between the ages of eight and sixteen. To my observation he is, notwithstanding those years of schooling, not well educated. To my observation, too, he does not have the good fortune to have a high mental acuity. By reason of the many matters I have outlined, and my observations of him, I treat his evidence with the utmost reserve, and would not accept it on any significant matter without some corroboration. Indeed, I took Mr Maconachie, who called him, to concede that to be the only appropriate approach. Did Mr Bell Ever Tell Anyone About Mr Davis’ Involvement Before He told Insurance Investigators on 23 January 2004?113 Before I leave Mr Bell’s evidence, I shall consider further the issue of who Mr Bell allegedly told of Mr Davis’ involvement, and when.(a) Mr Dee said he was never told, although Mr Bell at the first trial said he had told Mr Dee as they walked up the hill. It is not the sort of thing I would have expected Mr Dee to have forgotten, given he was the person independent witnesses claimed (through the caravan registration number) to have been to blame.(b) Mr Bell said at the first trial he had told Mr and Mrs Hodgkin on the day of the accident, whereas on 29 January 2004 he told investigators he had not told them. I have referred above to the reason for drawing a relevant inference by reason of their absence.(c) At the first trial Mr Bell said he told his father at the Canberra Show the following week, whereas he told me he phoned his father and told him on the day of the accident. In the end I took Mr Bell’s evidence to me to be that the only person he had ever told before the investigators had been his father.(d) Mr E Bell told me his son had phoned him on the day, and told him, and this had been the first time he had known, but at the first trial he said Mr Hodgkin had phoned on the day of the accident and had been the first to tell him.(e) Mr Bell’s fiancée, Melissa was not called, although at the first trial Mr Bell said he had mentioned Mr Davis’ involvement to her as they walked up the hill to their truck. (f) There were no telephone records in evidence on this or any other issue.(g) I take into account what I have said about the credit concerning Mr Dee, Mr Elwin Bell and Mr Owen Bell, and the absence of Mr and Mrs Hodgkin and Mr Owen Bell’s former fiancée.Conclusion 114 I accept Mr Elwin Bell’s evidence that he learnt of Mr Davis’ involvement on the day of the accident. I find it probable he learnt of this from Mr Owen Bell. I find that he accepted the truth of what he was told. I am not persuaded Mr Owen Bell told anyone else at the time. That is not to say it was not the subject of discussion between Mr E Bell and Mr Hodgkin. I think it probable there was such a discussion, given Mr Hodgkin was Mr E Bell’s overseer. It is probably not necessary to resolve the question of how the information came to Mr Hodgkin, but I consider it probable it came to him from Mr E Bell.Evidence of Dean Davis115 Mr Davis bought an unregistered Isuzu truck in Coffs Harbour at a time when he had only a car driver’s permit. The cabin of the truck was white. It had a white pantech on the back. It was registered in Queensland on 10 May 1999. It was sold after the accident. 116 Mr Davis bought a caravan in 1999. He had the registration transferred to his name on 11 May 1999. Its registration number was 001 QCM. The caravan was 22 feet in length, and cream in colour. At front and back was written the word “Scenic”. It had three windows on each side, one at the front and none at the back. At the back was a steel rack with two tyres mounted on it, about 1 to 2 feet apart. The caravan had 2 or 3 stripes on the side, but he did not recall the colours. A bucket game and a ladder game operated by Mr Davis at shows were carried in the truck. 117 He used the truck to pull the caravan. Stacey Grey was his girlfriend at the time he bought the caravan. They had been together then for about two years. Before that he had travelled with his parents.118 Mr Davis told me he and Ms Grey separated at the end of 2001 or in early 2002. Then Jordan, their child, lived with her. They continued to communicate until one or two years ago. He said Jordan has lived with him since April 2008. In mid 2008 Ms Grey had two conversations with him and told him that private investigators had been to see her and that she would do anything to make sure he goes to gaol. On occasions she has called him some offensive names. He told me he had not socialised with Mr Owen Bell since 2001, and he has never had a vehicle with a registration number similar to F34209. 119 He said he did not go to the Bega show in 2001 and never had any intention of going. He did go to the 2001 Nowra show. It finished on Saturday 10 February. On 11 February at 7am he drove his truck to Sydney. He left the caravan at Nowra showground, as the road to Sydney was hilly and he wanted to get to Sydney quickly. There was nowhere to park the caravan in Sydney. He had an employee at the time called Michael, who worked with him for two months. He did not know his surname. Michael was in his mid twenties and was his driver. On the 11th February, Mr Davis, Ms Grey and Michael, were in the truck. They got as far as Blakehurst, having crossed Tom Uglys Bridge. He received a phone call. The event in Sydney had been called off because of rain. They turned around, returned to Nowra, packed up the caravan and drove to Canberra, where he had intended to go after his trip to Sydney. He stayed at the Canberra showground for two nights. While there he bought some show prizes. At that time he saw at least ten people he knew, also staying there. Then he went to the Gundagai show, which was on at the same time as the Bega show. After the Gundagai show he returned to Canberra for the Canberra show. 120 On 11 February 2001 he was nowhere near Bega, and was unaware of any accident having happened near there. 121 Mr Davis’ denial of any involvement in the collision was the subject of substantial challenge.Mr Davis’ Credit122 There were matters about Mr Davis’ credit I found troubling. (a) Driving:  
     
     (i) In her evidence Ms Grey said Mr Davis always drove his truck, although unlicensed, and had been driving it at the time and place of the collision. Thus one can readily see that Mr Davis had a motive to lie about being both present, and driving, at the accident scene. 
      
      
     (ii) In February 2001 he only had his learners permit 
      T658.40 
     , and he knew that did not permit him to drive his truck. 
      T659.11 
       
     
     
     (iii) Mr Davis told me that before he got the truck registered, his father got a friend’s “staff” to drive it to Queensland, 
      T659.31 
      whereas he told Judge Coorey his brother had driven it there. 
      T659.44 
     
     
     (iv) Asked whether he had ever driven his truck between 1999 and 2001 he told me, “ 
     I think I drove it once.” 
      T661.36 
      That had been in Queensland and a distance of sixty kilometres and at a time when he had the caravan attached to the truck.  
      
      
     (v) Later he said he had not driven it at all in 1999, 2000 and 2001, and that the one occasion  
     “Might be 2002, 2003, something like that.” 
       
     
     
     (vi) Then he admitted that in 1999 to 2001 he had driven it:  
     “Maybe round the showgrounds or something like that.” 
       
      T662 
       
     
     
     (vii) When he gave evidence to Judge Coorey he told his Honour that as at February 2001 he had driven the truck  
     “short distances, not very far though’  
     and  
     ‘short distances on the road,’ 
      including, on at least one of those occasions, while towing his caravan. In cross-examination by Mr Black when giving evidence to me he said: 
     
     
      
       
        
        “Q. So on the assumption that what I have read out to you accurately reflects what you said in 2004, it is now your evidence that you may have driven your truck sometimes with the caravan attached between 1999 and 2001, is that correct? 
         
        A. If that’s the evidence I gave back then, well, yes.”  
         T663.41-45 
        
       
      
      
     (viii) Mr Davis said he could not remember when he actually obtained a truck licence. This evidence was given: 
      
      
       
        
        “Q. Can I suggest to you that you first got your provisional truck licence in August 2004? 
         
        A. I can't remember off the top of my head. 
         
         
        Q. And between 2001 and 2004 you drove the truck with or without the caravan from time to time, didn't you? 
         
        A. 90% of the time - 99% of the time I wouldn't have drove it. 
         
         
        Q. How many times do you say constitute the other 1 or 10%? 
         
        A. I couldn't tell you. 
         
         
        Q. More than once? 
         
        A. Maybe twice. 
         
         
        Q. Before you were prepared to swear that you had only driven it once after 2001, do you now concede that it was more than once? 
         
        A. Yes, I do. 
         
         
        Q. Were you lying when you said once a few moments ago? 
         
        A. Well, no, to my recollection that's all I can remember. 
         
         
        Q. What's come about in the last few minutes that has improved your recollection so that you can remember that you drove it more than once? 
         
        A. Well, you're sitting there reading the statement, not me.”  
         T664.25-48 
        
       
      
     
     
     (ix) Then there was the following evidence: 
      
       
        
        “Q. Do you say that from time to time both before and after February 2001 you drove the truck on occasion? 
         
        A. Yeah, very rarely. 
         
         
        Q. And that included driving it on the highway? 
         
        A. Might be out in the middle of nowhere, yes. 
         
         
        Q. That included towing a caravan? 
         
        A. Yes. 
         
         
        Q. When you were towing the caravan normally that would be when you were travelling from one show to the next? 
         
        A. Yes. 
         
         
        Q. So it was your practice that sometimes when you were travelling from one show to the next you would drive your truck and caravan, is that right? 
         
        A. I guess so.”  
         T665.14-30 
        
       
      
     
     
     (x) Mr Davis agreed he had been caught driving without a licence in 2002, and in 2006 he had been caught without an appropriate licence.  
      
      
     (xi) Mr Davis maintained he always had a driver who drove his truck and if he did not,  
     ‘I used to get my dad’s employees to drive it.” 
      T666.15 
      At the first trial he had said if he did not have someone employed to drive he would get his brother to drive. 
      
     
     (xii) Mr Davis had good reason to be dishonest about having been at the accident site as he lacked a driving licence and had, if Ms Grey is to be accepted, been the cause of the collision. 
    (b) Bega Show: Mr Davis told me he had not been at the Bega show in 2006. But when it became apparent there was evidence to the contrary (as there was) he said “Well if I was there and you’ve got evidence of it I was obviously there, mate.”  T667.34(c) Book Keeping and Income Tax: Mr Davis agreed that in 2001 he paid no tax on his income, paid employees in cash, kept no wages books, made no tax deductions from wages, kept no workers compensation insurance, and used his pockets as his principal bank account.(d) Caravan: At the first trial he said his caravan had three stripes, but to me he said it had two. (e) Attitude To Tax Laws: Mr Davis expressed amusement when it was put to him by Mr Maconachie that in 2001 he decided what laws to obey and what not to obey, in particular, tax laws T816. Then he admitted convictions for a number of offences including assaults occasioning actual bodily harm, in 1997 and in 2001. He admitted that in 2001 he was a man given to violence and had been violent to Ms Grey – though he said she had been violent to him, too.(g) Demeanour: To my observation, at times Mr Davis treated these court proceedings with some levity. When cross-examined on a document which he considered irrelevant to the case; he laughed and spoke over the cross-examiner T694-697 and displayed signs of volatility. But I do consider that a witness, especially as Mr Davis is, poorly educated, and unused to court proceedings, may well have a natural inclination to laugh in such a situation. 
    123 There were some positive, and some neutral, matters: 
     
      
      (a) There was evidence before me that in September 2001 the police learned that Mr Davis was working at the Young show, and in police uniform travelled to Young to interview him about the accident, but were told, when they got to Young, that he had left. That evidence was relied on by the interests who were attacking Mr Davis as evidence of flight, consistent only with a guilty mind. I am not satisfied the failure of the police to find him, and being told he had left, is necessarily significant. They were in uniform and it is not unknown in tightly knit circles for people to lie to police when they go looking for a member of that circle. I infer show people may have misled police by giving them false information, without Mr Davis necessarily having had any involvement. 
       
       
      (b) Although Mr Davis sold the truck and caravan after the accident, he did not do so for quite some time. He still had them when police interviewed him in February 2002. Nor did any of the parties opposed to his interests, suggest the vehicles were incapable of being traced. 
      
     
     
      
      (c) Mr Davis’ accounts at the two trials were reasonably consistent with each other and with what he told police. 
      
     
     
      
      (d) I agree with Mr Seton’s submission that Mr Davis gave his evidence in a confident fashion. However I reject Mr Seton’s description of him as ‘non-evasive’. I consider he was evasive, especially about his driving history. 
      
     
     
      
      (e) I agree with Mr Seton Mr Davis seemed appropriately indignant when propositions were put to him which (if he were truthful) were incorrect and/or illogical. Though Mr Seton submitted he had not been caught out or shown to have been a contradictory witness, I disagree for the reasons shown above. 
      
     
     
      
      (f) I agree with Mr Seton that Mr Davis made a number of admissions against his own interests, such as: 
      
     
     
      
       (i) Conceding he knew it was possible before the Five Dock function was called off that it might be called off; 
       
       
      (ii) conceding that Mr Melonas had facilities at Hoxton Park which offered a convenient place to park his caravan; 
       
       
      (iii) acknowledging his vehicles were not garaged at addresses at which they were registered;  
      
     
     
      
      (iv) acknowledging advantages there would have been to him by taking his caravan to Sydney, such as fuel costs, and having better roads to travel on. 
       
       
      
    124 Overall, I was left with the clear impression Mr Davis, while in some ways apparently quite a straight forward witness, was not to be trusted in areas of importance. Tender of MFI#27: Extracts From Mr Davis’ Evidence at the First Trial125 At the conclusion of the trial, Mr Seton tendered MFI 27. I rejected the tender but said I would give my reasons now. These are my reasons. MFI 27 consists of seven pages of transcript from the first trial. Three pages (1500, 1501 and 1503) are from Mr Davis’ evidence in chief and the other four are from his cross-examination. Some parts were tendered as “context” evidence and others as prior consistent statements. The first section, lines 40 to 43 on p. 1500 were said to be context evidence. They followed 32 lines of examination concerning the route Mr Davis said he took to Sydney on leaving Nowra. At line 29 he described a shop he saw after he crossed a bridge when coming into Sydney. He said, “there’s a blue bait and tackle shop and a fish and chip shop just over a bridge”. The four lines tendered I rejected as they amounted only to counsel’s asking him to repeat an answer earlier given and added nothing, in particular, to “context”. In any event I consider the time to tender that and other “context” material was when the witness was in re-examination.126 Next, it was said lines 49 on p. 1500 to line 26 on p. 1501 were a prior consistent statement. But in the evidence Mr Davis merely gave a description of some roadway he said he was on when he received the telephone call telling him of cancellation of the event in Five Dock. There was nothing in his evidence to me significantly different from it. Counsel for the other parties did not suggest his evidence at the first trial of travelling to Sydney by a route which took him over a bridge near shops (as described in the passage) was inconsistent with evidence he gave me. In fact the two versions are consistent. Further, although counsel for other parties did suggest that evidence was fabricated, and that he was really on his way to Bega at the time, the statement said to be ‘consistent’ with the one he made to me, was made in his evidence to Judge Coorey almost four years after the event. The exercise of the discretion under s.108(3) depends on the effect of the evidence on the witness’ credibility: R v DBG [2002] NSWCCA 328 at [50]-[51]. I am unable to see how that evidence can assist me to decide whether Mr Davis’ evidence to me is fabricated. In other words, I do not think it has any effect on the suggestion of fabrication. It lacks importance: s.192(c) Evidence Act.127 Next, Mr Seton tendered lines 15-57 on p.1550 to and including lines 14 on p.1551 as a prior consistent statement. It is part of his cross-examination at the first trial. It shows a consistency in Mr Davis at both trials in asserting that though he initially said he travelled by the F5, he really travelled all the way to Sydney on the Princes Highway. Mr Seton submitted this evidence put in context Mr Davis’ apparently adamant attitude that he was on the M5, though he clearly was not. However I rejected this evidence for the same reasons I rejected the previous portion of evidence said to have been context evidence. 128 Finally, Mr Seton tendered lines 19 to 44 on p.1575 from the first trial, as a prior consistent statement. But for the same reasons I rejected the other passage said to be a prior consistent statement, I reject this portion. 129 I shall return later to say more about the issue of Mr Davis’ credit. Evidence of Mr Leslie John Davis130 Mr L. J. Davis brought up Mr Davis and is his grandfather, though he apparently is treated as and called by Mr Davis, his father. He was at the Nowra Show in 2001. As at 2001 he recalled Mr Davis had owned a truck and caravan for a year or so. Mr L. J. Davis had been to the Bega show in the past. When Mr Davis bought the truck and caravan, Mr L. J. Davis said he ceased to work for him and had to find thirty-five foot of “space”. That was said to be the position in 2001-2003 and prior years. 131 At Nowra in 2001 he had quite a bit of space. In February 2001 Mr Davis took some of his space.132 On the morning of 11 February Mr L. J. Davis left Nowra to go to Bega. On the Wednesday or Thursday before 11 February 2001 Mr Davis told him that after being in Nowra he intended to go to Sydney to do a festival with a Mr Peter Melonas and then travel to Gundagai. In cross-examination he was not challenged about that statement of intention.  
     
      
    Credit of Mr Leslie John Davis133 It was not submitted by any party that I ought not accept Mr Davis’ evidence. He gave his evidence by telephone. In support of the application to have his evidence given by telephone, Mr Seton tendered medical evidence to show he could not travel from his home in Yatala, Queensland. Ironically, on the day he gave evidence, he was in Grafton, and said he had recently driven to Wollongong, towing a caravan.Evidence of Colin Michael Fowler134 He is a retired police officer who in 2001 was stationed at Dapto. He received a call about the accident and visited the scene. He was given the number Mr Lear had taken from the caravan he had identified as the offending vehicle. Two days later he went to the Bega showground to see if he could identify the caravan whose number had been passed on to him by Mr Lear. Neither he nor those officers with him had been able to find the caravan. Over the next few months some anonymous telephone calls were received by the Bega police or by him, suggesting Mr Davis’ involvement. Mr Fowler followed them up. 135 Mr Barry, who called Mr Fowler, tendered notes of the anonymous calls made by police personnel. Mr Seton objected but I allowed them in because I considered them to be relevant to the issue of “due search and enquiry”. They strongly suggested a legitimate line of enquiry as to the identity of the driver responsible for the collision and were thus highly probative on that issue. They were not tendered for the truth of the assertions. So I could see no prejudice to Mr Davis. Mr Barry tendered, and I admitted, a document sent to Queensland police on 8 August 2001 with MFI ‘1’, Mr Lear’s statement to police. I admitted the documents, not for the truth of their contents but as proof of what documents were sent. I reserved the question of whether Mr Lear’s statement would go in for all purposes, or whether its admissibility should also be limited. I admit Mr Lear’s statement only as to the fact of what he said. He identified his signature on it when he gave evidence. But it was not put to him that it was inconsistent with his evidence to me. One inconsistency in it, relating to whether he had stopped or merely slowed down when recording the caravan’s number, was put to him. But another, that he had not said to police when first questioned by them, the caravan’s number plate was black on white, and that he was not sure of the actual colour merely that it was “dark”, was not put to him. While it does not follow that a prior inconsistent statement must always be tendered after a witness has been asked to respond to inconsistencies in it, there is an unfairness to Mr Davis if I let it in for all purposes, when the number plate evidence is, as I find, so significant. 136 Mr Fowler said he had tried to find Mr Davis on several occasions. He eventually spoke to him on 24 February 2002, when he denied any involvement in the collision. On that occasion Mr Fowler looked at the caravan Mr Davis identified as his but Mr Fowler did not consider it fitted the description of the one he was expecting to see, based on what he had been told by others he had spoken to about the accident. T795 Mr Fowler arranged for Queensland police to interview Mr Dee and Mr Bell. Ironically, a variation in the caravan’s registration number appeared in his written request to Queensland police. But that I consider was a typographical error and had no bearing on the enquiry’s outcome or in this case. Messrs Dee and Bell were interviewed on 9 August 2001. Mr Dee denied any involvement in the collision, save for confirming he had been present. Neither mentioned to police the presence of Mr Davis at the scene of the collision. Mr Fowler’s Credit137 No question arose about Mr Fowler’s credit. But insofar as it is relevant, I consider he gave his evidence honestly, and doing his best to be accurate. He seemed to me not to have a clear recollection of anything associated with his investigation however. He had long ago left the police service and I did not find it remarkable his memory of some matters was vague. He did have a clear memory for some things, such as having had printer problems when taking a statement from Mrs Broughton. 138 I shall now deal with some particular factual issues of significance.Mr Davis’ Alibi139 It is to be recalled that Mr Davis said he left his caravan in Nowra, drove to Sydney to attend a fair at Five Dock, got a substantial way there, received a telephone call saying the event had been cancelled because of rain, turned around, returned to Nowra, hitched up the caravan, drove through the Kangaroo Valley to Canberra, where he obtained some toys for show prizes, stayed several nights, and went to the Gundagai show. Thus he was nowhere near the accident site at the time it occurred. (a) I accept Mr L. J. Davis’ evidence that Mr Dean Davis told him during the week before the accident that he intended to go to Sydney after Nowra; he was not challenged on that evidence; I accept Mr Seton’s submission that having finished at Nowra and if he had no other show till the Gundagai show and intended to go to the Gundagai show the following weekend, it made sense for him to go to Five Dock for a day to earn some extra money;(b) Mr Davis said, and I accept, that Mr Davis had been to the fair at least once before the one on 11th February 2001; Ms Grey’s evidence was to similar effect;(c) Canada Bay Council records and meteorological records show very extensive rain fell in Ashfield (near Five Dock) on 6, 7 and 11th February 2005 and that games of the type Mr Davis had, were then excluded from the area where the fair was held; Mr Melonas had booked some space for sideshows; the decision to call off sideshow access was at 9.30 am on 11th February.(d) Mr Davis conceded to me however he knew prior to 11th February that there was a prospect the fair might be called off; Nowra had had heavy rain that week too;(e) Mr J. L. Davis said that he had less lettable space at the Bega show than he had at the Nowra show;  (f) Mr J. L. Davis and Mr Dean Davis, said that since Mr Dean Davis had acquired his own truck and caravan and no longer travelled with his parents, he had not travelled to the Bega show. But as the evidence shows, he did not stop going altogether; (g) Mr Melonas sublet a substantial part of Mr L. J. Davis’ space at Bega showground;  (h) He was in 2001 a close family friend of Mr L. J. Davis;  (i) He had also made arrangements to have games at the Five Dock fair on 11th February. I infer that once the Five Dock show was in doubt Mr Dean Davis would have been prepared to travel to Bega to see what work he could find, although there was not necessarily space available to him. There was no other near show before the Gundagai show;  (j) Apart from Mr Melonas’s significant presence at Bega, Mr Davis’ family had close connections with the Bega showground; further, his brother was to be there; (k) It does seem puzzling that he would go to the Canberra showground at a time when there was no show being held and no way of earning any income there. Though Mr Davis maintained he had to go to Canberra to get his game prizes, he conceded these prizes were usually ordered and delivered to show sites.  (l) There were no receipts for any of the goods Mr Davis says he purchased at Canberra; (m) However Mr Seton tendered a photocopy of a receipt made out to Mr Davis on 14 February 2001 for accommodation at the Canberra showground. Ms Grey said they were at the Canberra showground for several nights. There is thus no disagreement between her and Mr Davis on this issue. However Mr Seton put to me that the receipt is evidence he was not conducting himself in a way suggestive of an attempt to hide. Mr Davis told me he paid some money to a friend when he left Canberra, and asked the friend to pay for his accommodation. There is some substance in the argument; (I also note this has some relevance to Ms Grey’s credit, because of her suggestion Mr Davis was in effect hiding out at the Canberra showground.)(n) It was argued that it was somewhat illogical, if Mr Davis intended driving from Nowra to Sydney then to Canberra, to leave his caravan in Nowra, drive back to Nowra from Sydney, and then drive to Canberra on a much less agreeable road, the Kangaroo Valley route. It would have been so much easier, it was put to me, that he take the caravan to Sydney, where he could have camped at Mr Melonas’ home at Hoxton Park, and driven on the F5 from Sydney to Canberra. Both Mr Davis and Ms Grey said they had previously stayed at Mr Melonas’. Though Mr Davis said there would have been a charge for staying with Mr Melonas, and he had prepaid for the night at Nowra, the fuel costs involved in returning to Nowra then proceeding to Canberra via the Kangaroo Valley were, I infer, less than any such accommodation charge would have been. In any event I am not persuaded Mr Melonas would have charged him anything, given the close family relationship;(o) There was evidence that the Kangaroo Valley route was not the longest route from Nowra to Canberra: travelling down the south coast to Batemans Bay, then up the Clyde Mountain, to Braidwood, and along the Kings Highway to Canberra, is the longest route – 270 kilometres. The shortest is via the Nerriga Road, 202 kilometres, and that via Kangaroo Valley is 212 kilometres. If Mr Davis was being truthful about not wanting to take the caravan to Sydney, the route he says he took, through the Kangaroo Valley, does not seem to me, on the evidence, to have been an unreasonable route;(p) There were no receipts for fuel bought on the journey, or of any relevant truck servicing. The absence of contemporaneous documents is not necessarily significant, however, given Mr Davis paid no tax and kept no business records. Further, if he was not the driver of the offending vehicle and did not know this was alleged for quite some time, why bother to keep such documents if he ever had them? (q) Other Considerations: There was no explanation for the absence from the witness box of Mr Melonas. As Mr Stitt put to me, this was a central part of Mr Davis’ alibi case. Mr Seton put to me however that others could have called Mr Melonas. Mr Barry that he could not necessarily have improved Mr Davis’ case. I decline to draw the inference Mr Stitt invited me to draw. Apart from the fact that he was available to all, I am not persuaded he could have assisted to throw more light on the alibi case than there is.(r) The entrance to the Snowy Mountain Highway was conveniently located near the accident site, making it a simple and logical way for Mr Davis to get away from the accident scene and escape early detection. Even if he did not go straight onto it, there were other roads in the Bega area which connected with that road.(s) The evidence given by Mr Davis about having travelled to Sydney from Nowra via the M5 is, as I see it, a neutral factor. The journey as described by Mr Davis was consistent with his having travelled on the Princes Highway all the way. Although Mr Davis said at the first trial he travelled on the M5, I consider that could be an error on his part in describing the route through southern Sydney after travelling along the Princes Highway. Although it was put by Mr Black that Mr Davis had been adamant at the first trial he had travelled via the M5, I do not accept that description. Rather, as I see his evidence, he was adamant in describing the route he took, whatever the route was called. Overall I do not consider there is compelling evidence to reject the alibi, without regard for other evidence, such as that of Ms Grey.The Identification By Number Plate Evidence 140 There was a substantial body of evidence concerning number plates. (a) The number recorded by Mr Lear was what linked Mr Dee to the accident as the driver of the offending vehicle and led to there being a substantial case against him as the offending driver. Mr Lear and his daughter (both of whom were completely independent) said the caravan whose number they recorded, and which was at the top of the hill, was the one they had earlier seen being towed by the offending vehicle. Yet that evidence is puzzling, because both denied the relevant caravan had been the one Mr Dee said he was towing that day. (b) Mr Lear was adamant when giving evidence before me that the number plate on the offending vehicle had been black and white, had begun with an ‘O’ and had no state identification; whereas the Dee caravan, while it had the numbers and sequence ‘34209’, did not have an ‘O’, was not black and white, but green or blue on white, and had a state identification, namely that of Victoria. Further, evidence tendered by Mr Veigel’s counsel showed that at the time of the collision there was no current issued number plate in any Australian State or Territory, carrying the number which Mr Lear and his daughter say they recorded. (c) I have considered what explanation there may be for what on its face seems a series of errors: a) recording of the wrong number; and b) identifying the caravan at the top of the hill as the one towed by the offending vehicle, when they said it was not the one Mr Dee says he left on the top of the hill. Mr Lear told me that after he noticed what he took to be the relevant caravan, he stopped to take down the number. However his daughter told Judge Coorey he had not stopped but had simply slowed down. It was put to Mr Lear by Mr Maconachie that at the first trial he had said that he had just slowed down. His reply was, “Did I? I can’t recall.” But he maintained to me that he had actually stopped. Given his earlier evidence of having only slowed, and that of his daughter to like effect, I think it probable they only slowed – and did not stop. Given Mr Dee’s caravan had the last five of the six numbers Mr Lear recorded, and that those five were in the same sequence as on Mr Dee’s caravan, I consider that between father and daughter, they made an error, and wrote down ‘O’ instead of ‘F’ as the beginning of the sequence.(d) Quite apart from the fact that, as I am satisfied was the case, Mr Lear did not stop, the collision, I am satisfied, was a most dramatic event for both of them to have witnessed.
